title: 112_hr2532
content: The Act titled "United States Secret Service Retirement Act of 2011" allows certain members of the United States Secret Service to elect coverage under the District of Columbia Police and Firefighter Retirement System. The Policemen and Firemen's Retirement and Disability Act is amended to include coverage for certain employees of the Secret Service, allowing them to elect coverage under the District of Columbia Police and Firefighter Retirement System. The Secret Service Retirement Act of 2011 allows covered employees to provide notification and assurances to the Director of the Secret Service, make a lump sum payment for transition costs, and use their Thrift Savings Fund account. The Secret Service Retirement Act of 2011 allows covered employees to make lump sum payments from their Thrift Savings Fund account, subject to adjustments for social security contributions and benefits. A covered employee is defined as an individual appointed to the Secret Service Division or Uniformed Division in 1984. The Secret Service Retirement Act of 2011 allows covered employees appointed to the Secret Service Division or Uniformed Division in 1984, 1985, or 1986, who have actively performed protection-related duties for 10 or more years, are currently serving in the Secret Service, and are part of the Federal Employees' Retirement System, to make lump sum payments from their Thrift Savings Fund account. The Secret Service Retirement Act of 2011 allows covered employees to make elections regarding their retirement benefits, with notifications provided by the Director of the United States Secret Service within specific timeframes. The Secret Service Retirement Act of 2011 allows covered employees to make retirement benefit elections. The Director of the United States Secret Service notifies employees of transition costs according to subsection (c). The transition cost is determined by comparing estimated payments to the District of Columbia with the benefits payable by the Federal Government. The Secret Service Retirement Act of 2011 allows covered employees to make retirement benefit elections. The transition cost for each employee is determined within 60 days of the Act's enactment by the Director of the United States Secret Service, in consultation with relevant authorities, based on appropriate assumptions and methodologies. The transition cost for each employee is determined within 60 days of the Act's enactment by the Director of the United States Secret Service, in consultation with relevant authorities, based on appropriate assumptions and methodologies. The lump sum payment required under the Policemen and Firemen's Retirement and Disability Act can be made by directing a withdrawal from the Thrift Savings Fund. Upon direction from a covered employee, the Executive Director transfers the withdrawal amount to the United States Secret Service for deposit into the Contributions for Annuity Benefits account. The transfer is treated as a direct transfer under the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code defines a "covered employee" as an individual described in the Policemen and Firemen's Retirement and Disability Act. SEC. 3. TREATMENT OF REEMPLOYED ANNUITANTS. Section 8468 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to define a 'covered District of Columbia retiree' as an individual receiving benefits under the Policemen and Firemen's Retirement and Disability Act based on service in the Secret Service and who transferred to that retirement system. If a covered retiree takes an appointive or elective position, their retirement benefits may be affected. The Policemen and Firemen's Retirement and Disability Act benefits will be deducted from the pay of reemployed retirees, as if they were an annuity under this chapter. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations for this process, including accepting certification from the District of Columbia government regarding the retiree's benefits during employment. SEC. 4. PAYGO COMPLIANCE. The budgetary effects of this Act must comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010, as determined by the latest statement submitted by the Chairman of the House Budget Committee before the vote on passage.
